abstract: Companies in sectors without obvious connections to housing are starting to feel the sting from subprime mortgages.
snippet: Companies in sectors without obvious connections to housing are starting to feel the sting from subprime mortgages.
lead_paragraph: THE official story on Wall Street last week was that subprime chickens may have finally come home to roost — in the form of an $8 billion write-down by Merrill Lynch — but that earnings growth in technology and other sectors was strong enough to insulate the overall market from the housing meltdown. After all, profits at favorites like Apple blew past expectations, pushing the iPod-driven shares up 8 percent.
